tossups.question: Legendarily, red and white variants of this stuff resulted from Guanyin's blood and breastmilk. This stuff is depicted beneath a set of "air radicals" in the character for the form of energy called qi (chee). In an origin story for the Dragon Boat Festival, locals dropped this stuff into the river where Qu Yuan (choo yoo-EN) died while attempting to save his body. This stuff, which official records label Zhang Daoling a "thief" of, provides the popular name for a movement that sought to create a state consisting only of "chosen people" under a "Celestial Master." A Han dynasty movement of religious Taoism is often named for the fact that newcomers had to donate "five pecks" of this stuff. At East Asian funerals, this stuff is traditionally offered in a bowl with vertical chopsticks. For 10 points, sake is a wine made from what staple crop grown in paddies?

Resonance in one type of these stars creates graphical features called "superhumps." The yet-unexplained Blazhko effect affects a type of these stars that are qualitatively similar to roAps ("ROW-apps"). In many of these stars, when compression leads to an increase in temperature, it unusually causes an increase in opacity. One type of these stars forms when a mass-transferring secondary forms an accretion disk around a white dwarf. The helium-ionization-based kappa mechanism powers a type of these stars that are described by a relation formulated by Henrietta Swan-Leavitt. The instability strip of the Hertzsprung-Russell diagram includes the W Virginis and RR Lyrae types of these stars, some of which can be used as standard candles once their period is observed. For 10 points, Cepheids ("SEPH-eeds") exemplify what stars, whose luminosity changes over time?
tossups.formatted_answer: variable stars [or cataclysmic variable stars; or Cepheid variable stars until "Cepheids" is read; or RR Lyrae variables until "RR Lyrae" is read; or W Virginis variables until "W Virginis" is read; prompt on cataclysmic stars]
tossups.answer: variable stars [or cataclysmic variable stars; or Cepheid variable stars until "Cepheids" is read; or RR Lyrae variables until "RR Lyrae" is read; or W Virginis variables until "W Virginis" is read; prompt on cataclysmic stars]

tossups.question: Tom Junod (JEW-nud) criticized this author's "feint" technique of pretending to challenge a preconceived notion only to reassure it in an Esquire article stating this author had "[Run] Out of Tricks." This author wrote that "Haywood Hansell won the war" in his book The Bomber Mafia. This author argued that pilots from a country with a high "Power Distance Index" will avoid confessing mistakes in a book that compares Chris Langen and Robert Oppenheimer. This author's "Law of the Few" is based on the Pareto principle that 20 percent of the people will do 80 percent of the work. One of this author's books opens by examining why professional hockey players are often born in the early months of the year. This author of The Tipping Point claims that it takes 10,000 hours to achieve "greatness" in a field. For 10 points, name this Canadian author of Outliers.
tossups.formatted_answer: Malcolm (Timothy) Gladwell [The article in the first line was written in response to David and Goliath.]
tossups.answer: Malcolm (Timothy) Gladwell [The article in the first line was written in response to David and Goliath.]

tossups.question: An elderly character in this novel named Sadie Sutter attracts attention for striking a Chinese gong. A newspaper reporter finds that the protagonist of this novel once worked as a circus clown, but the public is largely indifferent to the news. The title character of this novel is repulsed to learn that a woman he goes skinny-dipping with is a 33-year-old grandmother. This novel's protagonist is blamed for killing his co-worker Bump by Memo, a woman who refuses his romantic advances. The hero of this novel is offered a $35,000 bribe by the Judge to compromise his performance against Herman Youngberry. This novel's protagonist literally knocks the cover off an object after being told to do so by manager Pop Fisher. For 10 points, Wonderboy splits in half near the end of what novel about baseball player Roy Hobbs by Bernard Malamud?

In "Symptoms of a Locked Jaw", this man sits on a chair as his mouth is sewn shut. This man exclaims "I'll cut stick and fly to Araby!" while recoiling from a flying cape in another image. Another image shows Jack Downing dropping an axe and this man raising a cane against a head wearing a top hat. Thomas Nast drew a statue of this man riding a pig with the inscription "To the Victors Belong the Spoils." Another cartoon calls this man a "general" "slaying the many headed monster." Whigs circulated a cartoon of this man surrounded by phrases such as "HAD I BEEN CONSULTED" and "BORN TO COMMAND." In that cartoon, this man steps on the Constitution and a document labeled "internal improvements" and "U.S. Bank." For 10 points, name this President depicted as a "king" in a political cartoon used against him during the 1832 election.
tossups.formatted_answer: Andrew Jackson [or "King Andrew the First"; or "General Jackson Slaying the Many Headed Monster"]
tossups.answer: Andrew Jackson [or "King Andrew the First"; or "General Jackson Slaying the Many Headed Monster"]

tossups.question: A compound with this functional group replaces sodium hypochlorite in a greener alternative to producing hydrazine in the Olin-Raschig (OH-lin-RASH-ig) process. One of these groups is present in a common tert-butyl ("tert-B'YOO-tile") oxidizing agent used in conjunction with a titanium isopropoxide-containing chiral catalyst. Another "hydro-" one of these groups is present in an intermediate of the cumene ("CUE-mean") process. The Baeyer-Villiger (BAY-ur-VILL-ig-uh) oxidation is carried out in the presence of either one of these functional groups or an acid derivative, such as m·C·P·B·A. A solution of anthraquinone is used in synthesizing a compound with this functional group, which forms a catalytic mixture with ferrous ions used to oxidize wastewater called Fenton's reagent. For 10 points, an O-O ("O O") single bond characterizes what functional group, whose simplest member has the formula H2O2 ("H 2 O 2")?
tossups.formatted_answer: peroxides [or peroxo groups; or hydrogen peroxide or hydroperoxide; or peracids; or peroxyacids]
tossups.answer: peroxides [or peroxo groups; or hydrogen peroxide or hydroperoxide; or peracids; or peroxyacids]

tossups.question: This thinker, who described people who observe the world around them but do not understand it as having "barbarian souls," also said that "lightning steers the universe." Hegel dated philosophy's origin to this thinker, whom Heidegger's Introduction to Metaphysics interprets as a predecessor to Christianity's "revealed truth" while discussing this thinker alongside Parmenides. This philosopher's statement that "the way up and the way down are one and the same" exemplifies the "unity of opposites". This philosopher believed in a universal "reason" that he dubbed logos. This philosopher's advice to have a "dry" soul follows from his belief that fire was the fundamental element. For 10 points, name this Ephesian Pre-Socratic whose conception of flux is summarized in his statement that one cannot step into the same river twice.

An institution set up by a monarch of this dynasty was replaced by the "Office of Special Advisors," one of the "Three Offices" of this dynasty. According to the Journal of the Royal Secretariat, a king of this dynasty attempted to reproduce a scholar's rain gauge. The "Easterners" and "Westerners" were factions of a "forest of scholars" that dominated politics during this dynasty. Four "literati purges" targeted the Sarim faction during this dynasty. Members of the yangban (yong-bon) class were killed by followers of the "Eastern Learning" Donghak religion during this dynasty. A king of this dynasty set up a scientific institute known as the Hall of Worthies. That monarch of this dynasty created an orthography that anyone could allegedly learn in a few days, known as Hangul (HAHN-gool). For 10 points, name this Korean dynasty that included Sejong the Great.

A rival to an early holder of this title supposedly created droughts out of spite after being strangled with a scarf. False rumors of a secret Russian treaty derived from the relationship between a person with this title and Agvan Dorzhiev (AHG-vahn DOR-jee-ev), who signed a 1913 friendship treaty without the authorization of this office. The Kashag council served both the amban (AHM-bahn) and people with this title until the 1950s. This is the highest office whose holders were selected using a golden urn following the publication of the 29-Article Ordinance. Güshi Khan was the main benefactor of a person in this office who founded the Ganden Phodrang government. The current holder of this office fled the People's Liberation Army in 1959 and relocated to Dharamshala (DAH-rum-SHAA-luh). For 10 points, give this religious title held by the leader of the Gelug (GEHL-ug) school of Tibetan Buddhism.

This trait was found to be more strongly correlated with "plasticity" than "stability" in a paper by Scott Barry Kaufman about people with this trait "in the 21st Century." All instincts arise from the "formative tendency" to possess this trait according to The Organism by Kurt Goldstein. The thinker who popularized this trait stated that historical figures like Eleanor Roosevelt and Albert Einstein must have possessed this trait in their book A Theory of Human Motivation. This trait is the last requirement for an individual to reach "self-transcendence." Being in this state, which can produce peak experiences, first requires meeting physiological, esteem, and aesthetic needs. For 10 points, name this state of fully using one's potential, which sits at the top of Abraham Maslow's hierarchy of needs.
tossups.formatted_answer: self-actualization [accept word forms; prompt on self-transcendence before mentioned]
tossups.answer: self-actualization [accept word forms; prompt on self-transcendence before mentioned]

tossups.question: This substance captures air while falling through a narrow tube in a Sprengel pump. The collision of electrons with this substance demonstrated the existence of energy levels in a 1914 experiment. An experiment in which this substance was submerged in liquid helium led Heike Kamerlingh Onnes (HIGH-kuh KAM-er-ling OHN-es) to discover superconductivity. An interferometer on a stone slab was placed on a trough of this stuff to reduce friction in the Michelson-Morley experiment. An electric current excites a vapor of this substance in fluorescent lamps. A convex meniscus is formed by this substance in a device in which either it or alcohol is contained in a bulb at the bottom of a tube, and then changes volume in response to temperature changes. Fahrenheit's design for the thermometer used - for 10 points - what metal, which is liquid at room temperature?
tossups.formatted_answer: mercury [or Hg or liquid mercury or solid mercury or mercury vapor] [The second line refers to the Franck-Hertz experiment.]
tossups.answer: mercury [or Hg or liquid mercury or solid mercury or mercury vapor] [The second line refers to the Franck-Hertz experiment.]

tossups.question: Dillibe Onyeama (dee-LEE-bay ohn-YAH-muh) was expelled for performing this action during a staging of Antony and Cleopatra at Eton College. Wayne Collett and Vincent Matthews were kicked out of Munich for performing a "forgotten" action of this kind. An oft-reprinted photo of people performing this action also depicts the Australian Peter Norman, who wears an OPHR badge promoting human rights. A Newsweek cover photo depicted Nelson Mandela performing this action after being released from Victor Verster Prison. Two San Jose State students performed this action during the playing of The Star-Spangled Banner at a stadium in the University City neighborhood in 1968. For 10 points, identify this action done by Tommie Smith and John Carlos at the 200-meter medal ceremony of the Mexico City Olympics, which involved displaying a Black Power symbol.
tossups.formatted_answer: raising a fist [or raising a black-gloved fist; or descriptions such as making the Black Power salute until "Black Power" is read; prompt on protesting]
tossups.answer: raising a fist [or raising a black-gloved fist; or descriptions such as making the Black Power salute until "Black Power" is read; prompt on protesting]

tossups.question: This actress legendarily inspired Grace Kelly's character in Rear Window via her affair with Robert Capa. This actress left the U.S. after Senator Edwin C. Johnson referred to her as a "free-love cultist." This actress had to break up a kiss every three seconds for a two-and-a-half-minute scene with Cary Grant in Alfred Hitchcock's Notorious. The problems of a character played by this actress are compared to a "hill of beans" in a monologue by a man who has "done the thinking for both of us." This actress starred in the films Stromboli and Journey to Italy, both directed by her second husband Roberto Rossellini. Catchlights were used to make this actress's eyes sparkle as she's told, "We'll always have Paris" and "Here's looking at you, kid" on a Moroccan airfield. For 10 points, name this actress who starred alongside Humphrey Bogart in Casablanca.

A section of this novel that draws on the book Hours in the Library, by the author's father, describes how ivy almost covers the protagonist's house due to the oppressive "Spirit of the Age." Knole House inspired a mansion in this novel with 52 staircases and 365 rooms. At the end of this novel, a gray goose flies over the protagonist's sea-captain husband. This novel's protagonist, who gets engaged to Euphrosyne (YOO-fro-zine) and marries Marmaduke Bonthrop Shelmerdine, falls in love with a Russian princess while at a Frost Fair on the frozen Thames. This novel's protagonist writes the poem The Oak Tree after falling in love with Sasha and is repeatedly criticized by Nick Greene over a span of 300 years up to 1928. For 10 points, name this novel whose gender-nonconforming protagonist was inspired by Vita Sackville-West, written by Virginia Woolf.

The nickname of the "German" version of this man was given to Joachim ("YO-uh-kim") von Sandrart. In 2021, Eike Schmidt reopened a structure named for this man containing some 400 chronologically-ordered self-portraits. Karel von Mander's studies of Frans Hals were inspired by this man, who supervised the design of the Studiolo ("stoo-dee-OH-loh") of Francesco I. Federico Zuccari ("zu-CAH-ree") completed this man's Last Judgment fresco on the inner cupola of Florence Cathedral. The Palazzo ("pah-LATS-oh") Pitti and Palazzo Vecchio are joined by a structure designed by this man, his namesake "Corridor." Cosimo I commissioned this man to design what is now the Uffizi ("uff-ITS-ee") gallery. Venetian artists appear in later volumes of a book by this man nicknamed the "Vite." The term "rinascita" ("rin-ASH-it-ah"), or "rebirth," was first used in The Lives of the Artists by, for 10 points, what Italian Renaissance art historian?

The creators of popular examples of these structures receive the Blue Flame Award from Addgene. One of these structures used in the Gateway system has an addiction module that encodes the toxin c·c·d·B. S. cerevisiae (ser-uh-VISS-ee-eye) has a two-micron example of these structures with no known associated phenotype. These structures are resistant to denaturation at pH 12, which is why alkaline lysis protocols are used to purify them in a miniprep. These structures' ori (oh-rye) sites determine whether they are high-copy or low-copy. Artificial ones often have a polylinker site that can be recognized by many restriction enzymes. These structures, which can be transferred through a sex pilus via conjugation, often encode virulence factors and antibiotic resistance genes. For 10 points, name these short segments of circular D·N·A usually found in bacteria

The protagonist of a short story recognizes a doctor from this place because of the way he spells "naphthenate." (NAFF-thuh-nayt) A man shouts "Comrades, I am the last!" before being hanged in this place. Leonardo de Benedetti co-wrote a Report on medical practices in this place. The Truce, or The Reawakening, begins with the author leaving this place, where nurses steal spoons from sick people in the Ka-Be. The protagonist tries to teach Jean the Canto of Ulysses in this place, the setting of the essay collection The Drowned and the Saved. Alberto and the protagonist steal ferrocerium from this place in the story "Cerium" from The Periodic Table. "The Story of Ten Days" concludes Primo Levi's If This Is a Man, which ends with the arrival of Soviet troops to this place in 1945. For 10 points, name this concentration camp used during the Holocaust.
tossups.formatted_answer: Auschwitz [or KL Auschwitz or KZ Auschwitz or Auschwitz III -Monowitz; prompt on concentration camp]
tossups.answer: Auschwitz [or KL Auschwitz or KZ Auschwitz or Auschwitz III -Monowitz; prompt on concentration camp]

tossups.question: A work for string quartet by this composer, which was called a "latent opera" by Theodor Adorno, uses an "A-B-H-F" motif that partially refers to its secret dedicatee. An opera by this composer introduced the vibraphone to the orchestra, while the three acts of another opera by this composer are respectively structured as a set of character pieces, a five-movement symphony, and six inventions. This composer's piano sonata uses the "developing variation" technique of a teacher who ultimately did not complete this composer's opera in which a baritone depicts both Dr. Schon and Jack the Ripper. Under a blood-red moon, the protagonist of his first opera drowns Marie after her rape by the Drum Major. For 10 points, name this Austrian composer of the Lyric Suite, Wozzeck, and Lulu, who was a colleague of Webern and student of Schoenberg.

A restricted form of this kind of event called the vivente rege curbed the influence of the archbishop of Gniezno (gee-NEZ-noh). The safe passage given to Stanisław Leszczyński (stah-NEES-wahf wuh-shay-IN-skee) undermined a secret treaty regarding one of these events that was signed with three black eagles. Participants in an event of this type signed articles named for Henry III of France, as well as the individualized pacta conventa. Under the Golden Liberty, all szlachta (SHLAHK-tuh) were allowed to participate in the Polish version of this kind of event. The Golden Bull of 1356 established rules for this kind of event, which occurred irregularly in Frankfurt and was dominated by the Habsburgs for over three centuries. For 10 points, Frederick of Saxony was among a college of eight Holy Roman officials who participated in what democratic events?
tossups.formatted_answer: royal elections [or elections of monarchs; or imperial elections; or elections for the King of Poland-Lithuania or Holy Roman Emperor; prompt on elections or prince-electors by asking "what was the election for?"; prompt on sejms or parliaments or diets]
tossups.answer: royal elections [or elections of monarchs; or imperial elections; or elections for the King of Poland-Lithuania or Holy Roman Emperor; prompt on elections or prince-electors by asking "what was the election for?"; prompt on sejms or parliaments or diets]

tossups.question: Description Acceptable. After throwing its leader into a stream, one man is offered to join this group after whistling for dogs during a battle with the leader. An alias used by a member of this group, Reynold Greenleaf, is also the name of a separate member of this group who participates in a competition for gold and silver arrows. Much and Nick are names attested to a member of this group who is the son of a miller. A quarterstaff-wielding member of this group is ironically named in contrast to his massive seven foot tall stature, while another member is a monk expelled from his abbey. Little John and Friar Tuck are prominent members of this group who collectively oppose the Sheriff of Nottingham. For 10 points, name or describe these people who help an English outlaw steal from the rich to give to the poor.
tossups.formatted_answer: Merry Men [accept answers indicating Robin Hood's companions or Robin Hood's gang, prompt on just Robin Hood]
tossups.answer: Merry Men [accept answers indicating Robin Hood's companions or Robin Hood's gang, prompt on just Robin Hood]

tossups.question: This organ degenerates in patients with a U·T·P·4 mutation, which occurs in Cree children in Quebec. This organ is destroyed by the toxin hypoglycin A found in the Ackee fruit. Ischemia can cause centrilobular necrosis of this organ. Autoimmune conditions affecting this organ are indicated by the presence of anti-smooth muscle or anti-mitochondrial antibodies. Damaged intermediate filaments in this organ form Mallory bodies. One disease of this organ can cause a flapping motion of outstretched hands due to increased ammonia levels. Spider angiomas and palmar erythema are stigmata of one disease of this organ, in which fibrosis causes ascites (uh-SIGH-tees) and hypertension of its portal vein. That condition of this organ can also cause jaundice. For 10 points, name this organ that scars in cirrhosis and is inflamed in hepatitis.

bonuses.leadin: This man died during the performance of a Tom Taylor play, whose line "you sockdologizing old man-trap" preceded an unexpected shot. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this politician, whose murder during a performance of Our American Cousin prompted poems like Walt Whitman's "O Captain! My Captain!"
Abraham Lincoln deals with the death of his son, Willie, in this contemporary author's novel Lincoln in the Bardo.

In this play by Suzan-Lori Parks, a character named Booth shoots his brother Lincoln, who allows patrons to reenact Abraham Lincoln's assassination using a cap gun in his job as a whiteface Lincoln impersonator.

bonuses.leadin: This quantity can be calculated using the Polanyi-Wigner equation. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this quantity. Negative one times this quantity over the gas constant gives the slope of an Arrhenius plot.

The Redhead peak maximum method can be used to find the activation energy needed for this process to occur. The Polanyi-Wigner equation describes this process, whose inverse is often used in nitrogen generators in a form facilitated by "pressure swings".
The Redhead peak maximum method estimates the relationship between activation energy and this quantity measured in Kelvins to be linear when the desorption rate is at a maximum.
answers: desorption [do not accept or prompt on adsorption]
formatted_answers: desorption [do not accept or prompt on adsorption]

bonuses.leadin: Charles Hartshorne distinguished the "classical" form of this belief from its non-deterministic counterpart in the book Philosophers Speak of God. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this belief in the "Perfect Self-Existent." Baruch Spinoza formulated the modern conception of this belief that reality is equivalent to God.
Spinoza summarized his pantheistic beliefs with the statements that "God is Nature" and "Nature is God" in this magnum opus, whose ideas are "Demonstrated in Geometrical Order".

A debate over Gotthold Lessing's Spinozist views sparked the "pantheism controversy" between Friedrich Jacobi and this member of the Haskalah movement. This philosopher defended the immortality of the soul in his Phaedon.
answers: pantheism [accept word forms; accept Classical Pantheism; prompt on existence or substance monism; do not accept or prompt on panentheism]
Ethics, Demonstrated in Geometrical Order [or Ethica, Ordine Geometrico Demonstrata]
formatted_answers: pantheism [accept word forms; accept Classical Pantheism; prompt on existence or substance monism; do not accept or prompt on panentheism]
Ethics, Demonstrated in Geometrical Order [or Ethica, Ordine Geometrico Demonstrata]

bonuses.leadin: A "parity" named for two types of these assets is dependent on the discount factor. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these assets. The "moneyness" of these assets is equal to the ratio of their spot and strike prices.

The absolute value of a quantity denoted by this letter is roughly equal to an option's percent moneyness. A quantity denoted by this letter is equal to the derivative of the option value with respect to the underlying instrument's price.
When positive and negative delta components are roughly equal, these collections of financial investments may be described as "delta neutral".

bonuses.leadin: The historian Agatharchides's (ag-uth-ARK-id-eez's) only fully extant text details the lifestyle of people living around this region. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this region that Herodotus claimed was the origin of the Phoenicians. A text named for this aquatic region describes the king Charibael (KAR-ib-ay-el) and the "Frankincense" kingdom.

The Periplus of the Erythraean Sea describes trade between Rome and cities belonging to the Chera dynasty, which was one of the three "king" dynasties of this ethnicity. A later radical organization based in Sri Lanka was named for "tigers" of this ethnicity.

Arrian was inspired by the Periplus to write a Periplus of this other sea. Xenophon's (ZEE-nuh-fon's) Anabasis (an-AB-uh-sis) claims that the Ten Thousand exclaimed "Thalatta! (THAH-laa-tah) Thalatta!" upon seeing this sea.
answers: Erythraean (er-ith-REE-un) Sea [or Periplus of the Erythraean Sea; or Periplus Maris Erythraei; or On the Erythraean Sea; prompt on the Red Sea]
Black Sea [or Euxine Sea; or Periplus of the Euxine Sea]
formatted_answers: Erythraean (er-ith-REE-un) Sea [or Periplus of the Erythraean Sea; or Periplus Maris Erythraei; or On the Erythraean Sea; prompt on the Red Sea]
Black Sea [or Euxine Sea; or Periplus of the Euxine Sea]

bonuses.leadin: The runner-up of this country's 2021 presidential runoff election was José Antonio Kast, a far-right candidate who is the son of a Nazi lieutenant. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country where that 2021 presidential election was won by the now youngest state leader in the world, the 35-year-old Gabriel Boric ("BOH-rich").
In the election, Kast drew criticism for vocally supporting this former Chilean dictator, whom his brother worked for as one of the "Chicago Boys."

The previous Chilean president Michelle Bachelet (BASH-uh-lay) drew criticism for publicly supporting Boric prior to the runoff election despite currently holding this UN position. In 2021, the office under this position shared the names of Uyghur (WEE-gher) activists to China by request.
answers: Augusto Pinochet (PIN-oh-shay) [or General Augusto Jose Ramon Pinochet Ugarte or General Augusto Jose Ramon Pinochet Ugarte]
UN High Commissioner for Human Rights [or the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights; or OHCHR; prompt on the United Nations Human Rights Office; reject UNHCR]
formatted_answers: Augusto Pinochet (PIN-oh-shay) [or General Augusto Jose Ramon Pinochet Ugarte or General Augusto Jose Ramon Pinochet Ugarte]
UN High Commissioner for Human Rights [or the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights; or OHCHR; prompt on the United Nations Human Rights Office; reject UNHCR]

bonuses.leadin: This scientist's last initial partly nicknames a massive textbook, alongside the last initials of his students and co-authors Charles Misner and Kip Thorne. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this oldest co-author of Gravitation. This scientist coined the term "wormhole," though it was probably an uncredited student at one of their seminars who coined the term "black hole."
Gravitation explains this physical theory, which built on a "special" theory its creator had proposed a decade earlier.

The usual front cover of Gravitation depicts an apple with these lines drawn on it. In general relativity, particles in free-fall move along these lines, which are the generalization of straight lines to curved spacetime.
answers: John Archibald Wheeler [The textbook Gravitation is nicknamed MTW.]
formatted_answers: John Archibald Wheeler [The textbook Gravitation is nicknamed MTW.]

bonuses.leadin: Ka and İpek see the director of the Institute of Education being murdered at a pastry shop of this name in the novel Snow. For 10 points each:
parts: Give this name. In a 1994 novel with this title by the same Turkish author, Osman becomes obsessed with a fictional book that has this title after Janan puts it down on his table.
A reference to the earlier novel The New Life is among the many intertextual features of the novel Snow, which is by this Turkish author of My Name is Red.

While narrating part of Snow, the character Orhan Pamuk describes writing this real-life Pamuk novel about Kemal's love for Füsun (FUR-sun). Pamuk established a real-world equivalent of this novel's title place, which displays 4,213 cigarette butts.
answers: The New Life [or Yeni Hayat; accept New Life Pastry Shop]
formatted_answers: The New Life [or Yeni Hayat; accept New Life Pastry Shop]

bonuses.leadin: This scale lends its name to the major 7#11 ("seventh sharp eleventh") chord. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this mode equivalent to a major scale whose fourth degree is augmented. A George Russell book is devoted to the namesake "chromatic concept" of this "sharpest" mode, constructed when one plays white keys from an F up to the next F.

Watching Guinea's Ballets Africains inspired Miles Davis's move towards modal jazz, culminating in this album whose primary pianist was Russell's student Bill Evans. Its tracks include "So What" and "Freddie Freeloader."

This saxophonist, who performed alongside John Coltrane on Kind of Blue, joined Davis's first quintet on Milestones to form a sextet. He popularized soul jazz with such tracks as Joe Zawinul's "Mercy, Mercy, Mercy" and his brother Nat's "Work Song."

bonuses.leadin: After being captured at the age of 92, this man died a when he was shot in the back by the English settler hired to guard him. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this man who succeeded his brother as Paramount Chief of the Powhatan. John Smith first encountered Pocahontas after this man captured him and brought him to Werowocomoco (WAIR-uh-woh-KOH-muh-koh).
Opechancanough led the Powhatan through their second and third wars against this English colony. One quarter of this colony's population was killed in the Jamestown Massacre.
This future Royal Governor of Virginia was responsible for the capture of Opechancanough in 1646. He was relieved of his position due to Bacon's Rebellion.

bonuses.leadin: The devil who slept with this creature's human mother tricked her into accusing her brother of rape, leading to his execution by a pack of dogs. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this creature with a snake's head, leopard's body, lion's buttocks, and hart's feet, whose belly produces the sound of "thirty pairs of yapping hounds." It is constantly hunted by Pellinore.

The idea that the Questing Beast symbolizes the horror of incest in Le Morte d'Arthur is supported by the passage just before its introduction in which Arthur begets this traitorous son via accidental incest.

Through King Pellam, Pellinore descends from this namesake of an epic by Robert de Boron. As a legendary founder of British Christianity, he brought the Holy Grail to Glastonbury, where his staff became the holy thorn tree.

bonuses.leadin: This empire's government was led by eight ministers known as the Ashta Pradhan (AH-shtah prah-dahn). For 10 points each:
parts: Name this empire whose bargi cavalry led raids in the countryside during its invasions of Bengal. Its namesake "resurrection" was spearheaded by Madhavrao I (mah-DAH-vrao the first) in the 1760s.

The Maratha Resurrection began after a defeat by the Durrani (doo-rah-NEE) Empire at a battle near this city. The use of artillery to frighten Ibrahim Lodi's elephants led to Babur's victory at a 1526 battle named for this city.
This empire began disintegrating after losing to the Maratha Empire in the Deccan War. Babur founded this Islamic Indian empire after the First Battle of Panipat.
answers: Panipat [or Third Battle of Panipat; or First Battle of Panipat]
formatted_answers: Panipat [or Third Battle of Panipat; or First Battle of Panipat]

bonuses.leadin: The Viterbi (vit-ER-bi) algorithm can be applied to "hidden models" based on these constructs in applications like speech recognition. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these constructs. Random walks can be modeled by these memoryless constructs, whose state depends solely on their immediately previous state.

Markov chains are characterized by a transition matrix and an "initial" one of these functions, which assign probabilities to outcomes. These functions include ones named "chi-squared" and "Poisson" ("pwah-SOHN").

The Google PageRank algorithm uses a Markov chain's convergence to a distribution described by this adjective, which is a normalized left eigenvector of the transition matrix. Statistical processes described by this adjective have a joint probability distribution that does not change when time-shifted.
answers: Markov chains [or Markov processes or hidden Markov models; prompt on Markov]
formatted_answers: Markov chains [or Markov processes or hidden Markov models; prompt on Markov]

bonuses.leadin: A psychography by Chico Xavier (SHAV-ee-AIR) recounts André Luiz's soul going to a place called umbral rather than undergoing this process. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this process, by which souls transmigrate from one form to another in Karmic religions.

Through his many psychographies, Xavier popularized this religious tradition in Brazil. Unlike Candomblé, the Brazilian religion of Umbanda syncretizes Indigenous and Catholic belief with this tradition that Allan Kardec codified in the 1850s.

Amazonian Mestre Irineu founded a Spiritist-derived religion named for this kind of person, whom Candomblé and Umbanda priestesses are called "mothers of." The religion of Regla de Ocha is alternatively named after the Lucumi language or after this kind of person.
answers: saints [accept Santo Daime; accept mãe-de-santos or mother-of-the-saints; accept Santeria]
formatted_answers: saints [accept Santo Daime; accept mãe-de-santos or mother-of-the-saints; accept Santeria]

bonuses.leadin: This lecture uses the allegory of a man who builds a tower, only for people to pull it down to look for "carvings and inscriptions." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this 1936 lecture, which discusses the overuse of its central poem as a historical record and describes its theme as "man at war with the hostile world."

J. R. R. Tolkien's lecture "The Monsters and the Critics" notes that the theme of man's "inevitable overthrow" is central to this Old English poem's depiction of the title figure's fight with Grendel.

"The Monsters and the Critics" describes "hostile" figures like this monster, who kills Beowulf in the battle at the end of the poem. Tolkien ends the lecture by claiming that Beowulf "must ever call" to Englishmen "with a profound appeal" until this monster comes.
answers: "The Monsters and the Critics" [or "Beowulf: The Monsters and the Critics"; prompt on, but DO NOT REVEAL, Beowulf]
formatted_answers: "The Monsters and the Critics" [or "Beowulf: The Monsters and the Critics"; prompt on, but DO NOT REVEAL, Beowulf]

bonuses.leadin: An annual tribute of one of these animals every All Souls' Day ended in 1798 after Napoleon's forces conquered Malta. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these birds whose Maltese variety the Knights Hospitaller paid as tribute for their headquarters. These birds of prey were commonly used to hunt for sport in the Middle Ages.
This sultan demanded 12 gyrfalcons from John II of France as ransom for John's son. This sultan was later taken captive himself and forced to watch his wife serve the victor of the Battle of Ankara.

After John Stanley's appointment to this position in 1405, two peregrine falcons were gifted at every English coronation through that of George IV. Stanley's descendants inherited this title related to an English crown possession until a succession dispute during the Elizabethan era.
answers: Bayezid I [or Bayezid the Thunderbolt; or Yıldırım Bayezid; prompt on Bayezid]
formatted_answers: Bayezid I [or Bayezid the Thunderbolt; or Yıldırım Bayezid; prompt on Bayezid]

bonuses.leadin: Copies of the Irises series Ogata Korin painted on these objects may have inspired Vincent van Gogh's own Irises. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these objects which diverged from similar fusama through the usage of tools like zenigata. The Kano School introduced gold leaf to paintings on these objects like one of cypress trees in Momoyama castle style.
The painter monk Sesson Shukei likely inspired Ogata's painting of these things, which are "rougher" than the "Great" one depicted in the first print of Hokusai's Thirty-Six Views of Mount Fuji.

Korin revived the Rinpa school with his brother Kenzan, a painter better known for art made in this material studied by Bernard Leach. Jomon artisans made "rope-patterned" art objects from this material using sancai colors during the Tang Dynasty.
answers: waves [or Rough Waves; or Great Wave off Kanagawa; or nami; or aranami; or Kanagawa-oki Nami Ura]
ceramics [or pottery; or clay; or earthenware; or porcelain; or brick; or obvious equivalents]

ceramics [or pottery; or clay; or earthenware; or porcelain; or brick; or obvious equivalents]

bonuses.leadin: In functional feeding groups, this behavior is paired with scrapers such as parrotfish who feed on algae from rocky places. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this feeding behavior contrasted with browsing in which herbivores feed on grasses and other low-growing plants. Manatees engage in this form of feeding by digging up plants using their flippers.

Bioaccumulation in seagrass meadows can be indicated by manatees' grazing habits, thus allowing them to serve as these species used to monitor pollutants. Manatees' sensitivity to Brevetoxicosis from red tides contributes to their usefulness in this role.
Kelp forests are destroyed by these animals' overgrazing, forming namesake "barrens." Sea otters are responsible for controlling the population of these spiky echinoderms in kelp forests.

bonuses.leadin: Paul Celan's poem "Tubingen, January" ends with this poet's neologism "pallaksch" which "sometimes meant Yes, sometimes No." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this schizophrenic poet who spent his last 36 years in a tower in Tubingen. He wrote the hymns "Der Ister" and "Patmos," and included a "Song of Destiny" in the epistolary novel Hyperion.
Holderlin was the favorite poet of this author of a series of "Delusion Notes." Holderlin presaged the ideas on the Apollonian and Dionysian found in this author's The Birth of Tragedy.
Holderlin wrote three drafts of a Greek-style tragedy titled for this man. Matthew Arnold's earliest draft of "Dover Beach" was penciled on the back of notes for a poem about this philosopher.
answers: Empedocles of Acragas [accept The Death of Empedocles; accept "Empedocles on Etna"]
formatted_answers: Empedocles of Acragas [accept The Death of Empedocles; accept "Empedocles on Etna"]

bonuses.leadin: The allegorical prologue of an opera by this composer is set in Hebe's palace, where Bellona intrudes, leading Cupid to depart from Europe. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this French composer of Les Indes galantes and such tragédie en musique as Hippolyte et Aricie and Castor et Pollux.

Like Rameau's Les fetes d'Hebe, Les Indes galantes is in a form combining opera with this other theatrical genre. At the Paris Opera in 1832, Marie Taglioni became the first of its practitioners to don a romantic tutu.

This man's tribute opera Les muses galantes failed to delight Rameau, who feuded with this Geneva-born creator of The Village Soothsayer during the Querelle des Bouffons and attacked his Encyclopedie articles on music.

bonuses.leadin: In a film based on a story by this author, Hae-mi dances to Miles Davis's "Generique" in front of a sunset. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author of the story on which Lee Chang–dong's Burning was based. A 2021 road drama based on another story by this author follows the stage actor and director Yusuke (YOOS-kay) Kafuku.
That 2021 film is based on Murakami's "Drive My Car," which takes its name from a song by this band featured in the movies A Hard Day's Night and Yellow Submarine.

Despite Paul and Yoko's approval of her Beatles-inspired film Across the Universe, director Julie Taymor's most successful project is this musical based on a 1994 film in which animal puppets dance to music by South African producer Lebo M.
